Reviews.Title: Defender Infrared Security Cameras Don't survive the outdoors
Reviews.Author: B. Kirby
Reviews.Content: I purchased an all-in-one (monitor/DVR) wih four cameras.  The installation was a cinch (except for the internet viewing access). About two weeks after having three of the cameras on the roof looking at three sides of the property, two of the cameras began getting condensation inside the lenses. Support told me to send them back or remove the lense covers and wipe the glass. I wiped and they worked fine for a couple of days. I'm in Florida and if high (not that bad) humidity in November is a problem-imagine what will happen in July and August when the rains start. I plan to return them and see if the new ones leak.I am still working with Defender to see what they are willing to do. The support (telephone) department seems to be handled by one very busy, polite young lady. We'll le tyou know how it turns out. My warranty is ticking.Good Luck with your search.

Reviews.Title: The SN-300 4ch-001 DVR Security System *Just what I needed*!
Reviews.Author: J. R. Barrett
Reviews.Content: I replaced my 15 year old VCR based Black and White security system with the Defender SN-300 color Security system with 4 Nightvision cameras for my small retail business.  In the past, it was difficult to see a small 9" quad screen in B/W.  Now I have a 19" color monitor hooked to the Defender DVR and the difference is huge.  I really like the ability to switch from quad view to one camera for monitoring and playback then back to quad again.  The picture is not HD quality, but is VERY, VERY good and clear.  The DVR in highest quality will record 7-10 days of monitoring only.  I haven't tried the low quality setting, but I am sure the DVR would record much, much more with the 500GB drive in the low quality setting!  The nightvision cameras are a must and light my office well for recording.  That was a huge bonus.  The setup is easy and the menus also are easy to use.  The networking is a little more of a challenge, but am working through this for watching the store from home.  All in all, you can't beat the system for the money.

Reviews.Title: Good first impression, with just a few quibbles
Reviews.Author: William W. Davis "famousdavis"
Reviews.Content: QUICK SUMMARY:  I setup this surveillance system (not really a security system) with minimal trouble.  It's doing what it's supposed to do WITHOUT having to call Tech Support, without reading the owner's manual, and without scouring the Internet for solutions to problems -- I didn't encounter any serious issues, and the few minor installation bumps I encountered were easily remedied.  Don't expect much from the "color" cameras - the default colors from them are abysmal (but for an inexpensive surveillance system, I'm willing to put up with lousy color).  I'll wait a month before deciding whether or not recommend this system, but overall, I'm pleased with what I've seen so far.What I LIKE:- Well packaged and complete.  It comes with a Quick Start guide and an owner's manual which is only slightly more informative.  You can do the installation just from the Quick Start guide, and refer to the owner's manual only if you need to.- It worked!  It does what it says it will do -- without having to call Tech Support for assistance.  Yea!!- The color "high-res" cameras (which are NOT "high definition") are really quite small and unobstrusive.- The cameras can be installed indoors or outdoors (but if outdoors, they must not be directly exposed to the elements, so says the owner's manual).- Lots of configuration settings let you decide which cameras to turn on/off, how many frames-per-second they'll record (from 1 fps to 30 fps), resolution quality, when to record, and more.  I haven't tried many of the features yet, like connecting to my home network, or recording only when the camera's sensor indicates something is moving within its narrow field-of-vision.- If I really want to have this system professionally installed in my home, there's an option the manufacture provides to do just that.  But I don't know what the cost of that would be.- The "night vision" feature (for darkly lit rooms or outside at night within ~15 feet of the camera) works pretty good!  I've never used "night vision" electronics before, and it's startling how clear someone's face can be seen using this feature.- At night using available streetlight, you won't be able to read a license plate from the video that's recorded, but you will be able to see the model of a vehicle driving by.What I Did **NOT** Like:- The default colors from these "color" cameras are awful.  The color green -- leaves on trees and the color of grass -- show up grayish-brownish-purpleish, NOT green, on both the live video feed and the corresponding recorded video.  Strangely, the only time grass and leaves show up green is during a torrential downpour of rain.  White and black show up well, orange shows up okay, but most other colors seem way, way off.  You can improve the colors by manually adjusting the hue setting for each camera.- Using the remote, sometimes pressing the "Menu" button (which should exit a screen and return to the main menu) instead caused the toggling of the configuration setting which was highlighted on the screen.- The 1st camera I connected to the DVR did not work until I connected the 2nd camera, and then both cameras worked.  I swapped the camera inputs on the DVR and still had an issue with one of the cameras.  I suspect a suprisingly loose connection between the video cable and the DVR to be at fault.  I stopped debugging the problem, though, once both cameras began working.- There is no chart that explains what types of settings will lead to what kind of disk usage within the DVR.  The retail box says it can record up to 2 years of video, but the fine print explains that is at the lowest frames-per-second (that is, 1 fps) and at the lowest video resolution possible.  In other words, you're not going to get 2 years of recorded video from this unit!  After a few days living with this system, I found that I could record a total of 20fps (among all 3 cameras combined, where all cameras are set to the highest quality resolution), and that uses about 7%/day of the hard disk space.  So, in my installation, I'll get about two weeks' worth of recorded images before I begin overlaying the oldest images with newer images.What Could Be BETTER:- The camera's field-of-vision is very narrow, and there's no adjusting that.  On the camera I installed outdoors, the field-of-vision 30 feet away is about the width of my double-wide driveway plus the mailbox.- The zinc-plated hardware (wood screws) used to install the cameras will rust quickly outside, even if they're not directly exposed to the elements.- There is no glitz when it comes to the menu user interface.  It's like something out of 1980.  Just white, block text...no icons, no graphics, no media bling at all.- The tightening screw on the installed cameras (that applies pressure to the ball-and-joint of the stand) tends to keep the cameras from moving vertically out of place, but it still seems too easy to move the camera horizontally with a very light touch.  I need to investigate this some more to ensure it's not "user error" though.  The cameras themselves aren't moving out of place, but with a strong wind outside, I'll bet they would.BACKGROUND:  I already have a home monitoring system -- that is a much better deterrant than a 4-camera surveillance system.  If all you're relying on is this system to protect your home or business, a burglar can easily haul off the Defender's DVR unit, leaving you empty-handed and without any video proof of the crime!  But a surveillance system has many other uses and benefits.  It's a great compliment to the measures you're already taking to secure your property.  For instance, what ARE my kids doing while I'm not at home and they're home alone?!INSTALLATION:  As I said already, it really was easy.  I mistakenly assumed I could connect the DVR to my computer and use my computer to do the setups.  Afterall, the DVR has an Ethernet jack and it comes with an Ethernet cable.  But you can't configure this DVR using your computer -- you *must* use either a TV or a monitor with an RCA-type video input.  So, I moved the DVR from my computer desk over to the home theater armoire in the family room, and quickly connected it to my Samsung LCD TV.  Right now, I've connected one camera atop my armoire, and another two outside my home overlooking my driveway, street, and walkway up to our front door.Note for Northerners:  The operating range for these cameras is 14°F ~ 140°F, so if you live in a part of the country that gets very cold in the wintertime (I don't!), this may be of concern to you if you plan on installing any of these cameras outdoors.CONFIGURATION: Simple to do.  Hit "Menu" on the remote control, and walk through each menu choice to make your selections.  Hit "Menu" again after you make a configuration setting change, and "Menu" once more to update the settings on the DVR.VIDEO QUALITY:  Okay, don't expect to see anything approaching HD videos here!  The live video feed is probably like TV's standard definition.  The cameras struggle with most colors, like green, navy or dark blue.  Other colors, like honey oak on our table, look good.  Indoor lighting can get screwy if you're using a combination of different lighting equipment within the same camera's field-of-vision (for instance, my kitchen with fluorescent lighting in the foreground looks okay, but the background incandescent lighting in the dining room causes the walls to look faintly purple). By default, outside colors are awful.  Tree leaves and the grass outside look gray-brown-purpleish using the camera's default settings.  If you change the "hue" setting for cameras placed outdoors from the factory default 64% setting down to 40-50%, tree leaves and grass obtain an acceptable green color.  Most everything tends to look washed out, but the objects you'll see in this video -- people or pets, for instance -- are easily recognizable.  In other words, it's "good enough" to be useful, as you won't be using these video cameras to record baby's first steps!  Recording at the "Highest" resolution setting won't be quite as good as the live video streaming.  Lower resolution settings just make the recorded video look that much worse.  My suggestion is to take some short video samples and see which resolution you can live with.  Note:  There is no audio feed coming from these cameras -- you only get video.CONCLUSION:  I've only had this system for less than a week, but I like it.  It can help identify the goings-on around and inside my home.  I'll continue to update this review until I decide whether I'll recommend it or not.*** APRIL 27, 2010 UPDATEHere's how this system helped solve a mystery for me.  Yesterday, I left for work in a downpour. While backing out of my driveway, I ran over our garbage can which had been emptied by the city workers just a few minutes before!  Why did I run over my garbage can?  Did I not look behind me, before backing up?  Did the city workers place the emptied trash can directly behind my vehicle?  Later in the day, I watched the video and saw that the city workers had placed the emptied can at the corner of my driveway, but yesterday's storm blew over the can and pushed it directly behind my vehicle!  There was no one to blame; it was a freak incident.  The video explained exactly what happened.  Pretty cool!

Reviews.Title: SVAT SN300-4CH  - Very User Friendly
Reviews.Author: James Smith
Reviews.Content: I recently purchased this system directly from the vendor. Overall I feel that their customer service was just awesome. They were very knowledgeable about all systems and help me find the one that fits my needs. When I did purchase this unit, I was missing a power cable and they sent me one in 36 hours. I understand these things happen but they made good on their service.Very easy system to install. No problems doing so. I am able to view my house from work and find that very comforting. So far I would reccomend this product or any other product from Defender (SVAT).

Reviews.Title: Defender SN300, Low cost piece of mind for your home.
Reviews.Author: Gary Ruo
Reviews.Content: I have purchased this unit directly from Defender and it arrived within a week. Installation was a breeze and it was easy to hide the wires as there is only one small wire for each camera going from the cameras connector to the connection on the DVR. I did put the cameras under the sill of my home protecting them from direct rain and snow and so far I have had no issues with them. I did have one camera mount that did not work properly when I received the system so I contacted Defenders customer support and I had a replacement mount in two days. I must say so far I am quite happy with my purchase and also with Defenders customer service.  Having been the victims of theft prior to installing this system, my wife and I feel better knowing that our home is being watched even while we are not there. This time if the theives return I will have video evidence for the police. Night vision works great, even better if you have a little extra ambiant light such as a low wattage porch light to help illuminate the area.

Reviews.Title: I wish I could say nicer things...:(
Reviews.Author: William Hardin
Reviews.Content: I hate rating something low like this but sadly this Defender product earned this rating. I too ran into hard drive problems. I too had 2 cameras die due to them being used outside. I too struggled with trying to set up the remote networking part of the unit. Past that the software interface is ugly and awkward to use at best and the CMOS cameras (instead of more common CCD cameras) produced just decent quality video with off color (as others have reported).What others haven't reported as much is how much the product lacks compared to the other popular brands of cam/dvr combos. I have used 4 brands now with this being the worst package and with the most failures of any of them. (It is also the newest!)One thing to point out, is when shopping for these systems look at two very useful features. What is the quality of the cameras (including if the "outdoor" cameras really stand up to outdoor conditions) and how many feet the night vision works on as not all are equal. The second feature to make sure you look for is H.264 compression. This allows for maximum storage and less loss of quality which means you can record longer and the result will save better but you still need quality cameras. (The other two major points is overall failures and software/interface.)I hope this information helps you with your purchases and I look forward to trying out an updated Defender product should they release a better quality package.

Easy to set-up and lots of nice features, but they need a more dependable hard drive.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The Defender SN300 is a do-it-yourself home/office security system. It is very easy to install and really only requires a cordless drill. Overall installation can be done in 1-2 hours - in truth, it takes almost as much time learning the system and the menus as it does to do the installation.Features -- Nice crisp cameras- Lots of control over frame rates, recording times, and video quality- Ease of installation- Very easy to cycle through the camera- Everything you need is included - all of the cables are included!- Defender did a great job organizing the box. Everything is positioned in a logical organized method - this may sound crazy but it does aid in the ease of installation.Other notes-- Not Mac compatible - so if you are going to connect the SN300 to your network you will need to borrow or use a PC- The menu screen was a little slow - not much of a complaint- While the SN300 is not complicated it may take a while to learn how to operate through the system.Final Verdict- The SN300 is a excellent choice for homes and offices that need an easy to install security system. The cameras are crisp and the DVR has 2 years worth of memory so the SN300 is worthy of your consideration.---Please Note - I received the SN300 from the manufacturer for reviewing purpose-------

Reviews.Title: System very unreliable
Reviews.Author: CEdison
Reviews.Content: I unfortunately purchased 2 of these systems in April 2010 for use at a vacation home. Although the camera quality is average at best, the systems would be fine if they worked reliably over time.  But they do not. Both systems unexplainably stop recording from time to time, which is the last thing you need from a security system. And when the systems stop recording, remote Internet access is impossible. The final straw for me was the complete failure of the hard disk in one of the DVR units (apparently a common porblem), losing all content and making the system useless. I am sending it in for warranty replacement now, but the company says this will take 2 to 4 weeks. By the way, if you need to call support, for most calls you hang on for 10-15 minutes and then get a message that someone will contact you within 24 hours, which they generally do--but when they do you may not be anywhere close to the system they want you to reboot or adjust or whatever to diagnose the problem.  My conclusion: Do NOT buy this product. Given my experience and many other reviews, I am amazed and disappointed that Amazon continues to sell it.

Reviews.Title: Decent Balance of Features and Price
Reviews.Author: Home Studio
Reviews.Content: The Defender 4-camera security system has some impressive features for the price...and also some drawbacks that you should weigh before making a purchase decision.The Defender really is relatively easy and intuitive to set up (the trickiest part will be stringing the wires to your cameras...each can be up to 60 feet from the base unit). It should be noted that there is no monitor included with the system - you'll need to supply your own (with RCA jack inputs for video).In good lighting (indoors or out), the pictures are clear and have a relatively wide field of vision. At night, the infrared lights do a decent job of lighting a small area (approx 15 feet from the lens) but don't expect the light to do much in a larger space or outdoors. In my own tests with outdoor use, there was a huge amount of "noise" in the pictures once the sun went down. Maybe that's an unavoidable problem with light amplification, but it looked bad. In fairness, the picture clears up when something gets back within the 15 foot range.The DVR-style recording unit is extremely compact and can be controlled with a handheld remote. Unfortunately, the remote and base unit frequently didn't want to communicate, requiring multiple button pushes. Additionally, the small (very small) rubber buttons on the controls sometimes stuck in the "down" position (getting caught in the body of the remote itself) causing some confusion.An important component of the Defender is its ability to interface with a computer...but sadly, I couldn't test this. When they say that it works with your "PC," they don't mean just a "personal computer," but only a Windows machine (though the only place I could find this information was a small line printed on the bottom of the box). There is no software or support for Mac computers, and my query to the service department asking if Mac compatability was planned went unanswered.Similarly, I was unable to test the "online monitoring" function, which seems like it could be a big plus.All in all, the Defender seems like a good package for the price - assuming you have an appropriate TV monitor, a Windows computer, and either small or well-lit areas that you wish to keep track of.

Reviews.Title: good for home security - could be better
Reviews.Author: Dave
Reviews.Content: This all-in-one video surveillance kit is decent for home security.  Most other kits in this price range (as of this review date) offer higher-quality CCD cameras, smartphone support, FTP/e-mail alerts, and VGA/audio connections.  I learned this the hard way after making an impulse buy.  Oh well.  I am happy with it so far though.  I've used it for a day now continuously without any problems.  The included CMOS cameras display decent-quality video but the color is very washed out - it's like black and white with a smudge of color here and there.  With CCD cameras, that wouldn't be an issue.  I do not recommend using the cameras outdoors - I've owned weatherproof cameras in the past, and these ones aren't, despite what the manufacturer says.  The night vision is really neat and shows everything even in pitch dark.  However, in night vision mode, the cameras will be very sensitive and will display small particulates like dust in the air, which can trigger motion recording.  The motion recording works well, and the sensitivity seems nearly perfect.  Note there is 60 fps SHARED amongst all 4 cameras.  Using the max 60 fps at high quality will max out the storage quickly (in under a week).  At only 4 fps per camera (16 fps total), at highest quality, the video motion is still fluid and you should be able to get about a month or more of footage (using motion detection instead of continuous recording).  Using lower quality for recording is a waste of time since the resulting video will be very pixelated and blurry.  The DVR unit is small and compact - very easy to conceal if necessary.  It lacks a VGA display port and offers only BNC connections for input/output (with RCA plug adapters included).  No audio support.  The buttons on the DVR unit and on the remote are a bit flimsy but will work fine if you press them gently.  I had high expectations for the USB-to-PC feature but it's not much different than the network feature; in both cases, you must run a special client software program to use the DVR remotely.  Windows detects the DVR as a mass storage device, which is awesome.  However, since the DVR uses an oddball storage system instead of a standard FAT or Ext2/3 file system, you can't access the video files directly.  Therefore, you must use the special client program - you cannot use your own automated backup program.  Backing up video content using the client software is a bit tedious since you are forced to playback the footage you want to back up, and then wait for the AVI conversion (which is DivX, by the way).  The DVR runs in simplex mode, not duplex or triplex; this simply means that it can only do one thing at a time instead of offering simultaneous playback and recording.  The built-in configuration setup menu is simple to follow.  The networking setup is pretty straightforward.  You can have an administrator and a regular user account, both with seperate passwords.  You can also password-protect vital DVR functions.  Hard drive prep is a breeze - the DVR unit formats it very quickly.  You must format the entire drive if you want to delete any video from it, however - deletion of individual video events is not supported.  What's great is that you can unplug the DVR, plug it back in later, and it resumes operation seamlessly.  A power button would have been nice, though (geez!).  All in all, this is good for home security use.  If given another opportunity to buy something else, I would.  But I'm content with settling with this product since it works very well and has good support, despite some drawbacks.UPDATE (3 months later):Experiencing some major glitches with the DVR unit.  The case gets very warm and I suspect overheating.  I also had the dreaded hard drive glitch where the unit would not detect the drive.  After it cooled off for awhile, it began to work normally.  Also, at times the motion detection will simply revert to continuously recording from a single camera, usually when I need it the most.  A lot of footage was not recorded because of this.  Another issue is the unit simply malfunctions at times, showing incorrect dates like "14/16/2133" and locking up.  My overall experience has changed and I'm not very happy with this surveillance package anymore.  It sickens me to realize that I've spent close to $500 for something that is of mediocre quality.  The unit is still under warranty but based on other reviews I've read from people experiencing the same issues, it doesn't seem worth bothering with it.  I removed the case from the unit to try to prevent any further overheating and time will only tell...

Reviews.Title: Started out good - continued problem over and over for seven months
Reviews.Author: Jim "Jim"
Reviews.Content: At first this product started out working very well. I took the time to install the cameras in locations that would protect them in the weather. For example, cameras were installed under the overhangs of my house and under my elevated deck.I had my first camera fail just under a month of installing this unit. It is understandable that users may get defective parts so I did not have a problem with that. The customer service was great and exchanged out the camera for a new one.Shortly after, the DVR unit would randomly show a black screen with dates like "19/12/2199" and a time of all "99999" I performed a hard software reset hoping it would correct the issue but it did not. I contacted Defender again and they exchanged the DVR unit for what looks to be a new one. Sounds great but it took over a month for them to "test" it and confirm it was bad before returning it to me.Now I have the same problem again with a new unit expecting I will be with out this expensive product again for at least another month.Overall the customer service seems ok but the product is lacking. I have had this just over six months and it has only worked for three.I understand that there are defects expected, this defect rate is to much for me. I have jumped through their warranty and will NOT RECCOMMEND this.My credit card company will assist me in recovering my full purchase of this as I return it.BE CAREFUL WITH YOUR MONEY.......

Reviews.Title: Defender SN300-4CH Hard Dive Error
Reviews.Author: TCLAY73
Reviews.Content: I own a Defender SN300-4CH security system...for about a year and half but only used for the past six months.  Camera problems have been a week after I installed cameras the one outside by my sun room went out after a thunder storm...Blown by one little storm...WOW!!!  Second today 7/4/2012 my hard drive gave me a error reading No Hard Disk...well rebooted system and noticed on screen displayed NO HDD...So I did the next step which was to contact technical support via  live chat...waste of time people really...anyways I decided to open up the box to get to the hard drive...disconnected the cables and replaced then powered up and it corrected the error...maybe by this it reset the hard drive not sure but it worked and took a total time of about 5 minutes...I am writing this in the case someone might be encountering this error and are being told to buy new unit...please be advise if your one year warranty is up you have nothing to loose...I was told to upgrade but being a stubborn Engineer I refused and corrected the problem myself...hope this helps some of you...God BlessTroy...

Reviews.Title: Complete Piece of Trash
Reviews.Author: DK the DJ
Reviews.Content: VERY WEAK UNIT!  Worked about two months, Harddrive went out..."No HDD".  These people have no service centers anywhere.  BUY ANYTHING ELSE!  Don't even think about buying this DEFENDER!

Reviews.Title: Very easy to set up and great for what I use it for
Reviews.Author: J. Miller "Heresy"
Reviews.Content: I set this up to see the inside of my house and my dogs over the web and it works great. With the 4 cameras I am able to see the 3 main entry points and most of the living area & kitchen. The set-up was extremely easy (though computer/networking novices may have more issues) and the only real problem was running the cables which is quite a pain if you don't want cables out in the open. I did do a firmware upgrade after I installed the hardware so that may have helped with the lack of problems.If you are planning on using the cameras on the outside of a house/business you will probably need to get some extension cables for cameras since the ones they provide are relatively short. The 'night vision' cameras also seem to be pretty weak unless there is a decent light source; it's not like night vision goggles (in my case leaving the hall light on was enough to give the cameras what they needed.)

Reviews.Title: Easy to set up, good recording in low light and the dark
Reviews.Author: Bukkene Bruse
Reviews.Content: This product is being primarily marketed on the strengths of its ease of setup, and it is indeed completely trivial to connect the cameras to the DVR and the DVR to a television.  In this regard the system delivers.The form factor of the DVR is quite compact, and the cameras are small as well, only slightly larger than the old-style logitech ball webcams.The cameras record nicely, even in the dark.  The infrared images are like those from infrared 35mm film ([...]), not the more widely known heat fields that night vision goggles render that render no detail.The only issue I have is with the premise of easy setup.  You still need to run the camera wires, which dwarfs the amount of work and hassle needed to set up the electronics.  For many people this requires professional help -- they give you a number to call if you want it, and supposedly they'll install anywhere in the U.S.  But then the ease of setup becomes moot.

Reviews.Title: Easy and Affordable
Reviews.Author: Tom Kennedy "TSK"
Reviews.Content: Right out of the box I plugged everything in on the dining room table, and turned it on.  Four cameras recoding. Simple.I also got an inexpensive LCD VGA monitor, and if you do, be sure to also order a "VideoSecu 1L9 Composite Video to VGA converter". It plugs into the monitor, and the video output, and works great.My only "con" would be the RCA connectors could be more robust, to make more secure connections.

Reviews.Title: I wouldn't rely on this system
Reviews.Author: S. Potter
Reviews.Content: Old, long surpassed technology is the number one weakness of Defender SN300-4CH-001.  First, the cameras.  The Defender uses cheap CMOS cameras that have been on the market for around 10 years or so.  Yes, they don't use much power.  However, their image resolution is not on a level with even a cheap CCD camera.  In low light, even with the "night-vision" there is a great deal of camera noise. I am not confident the camera would provide a clear enough image to help identify the face of an intruder photographed at night in low ambient light.  The daylight images are much better but still lag behind those produced by CCD cameras.  If you are trying to safeguard your home at night, the Defender is not a good choice.The DVR is ridiculously backwards in terms of technology.  To set it up, you must hook it up to a television--greatly annoying if you plan to hook it up in a room with no TV.  I placed my DVR in my home office next to my computer.  I had to heft down, from the attic, an old school tube tv to perform the initial setup.  There are scads of inexpensive DVRs capable of connecting directly with a computer monitor.  Unless you plan on using the DVR in the vicinity of a TV the Defender will disappoint you.  The quality of the camera connectors is poor, as well.  It is necessary to first connect the camera output plugs to a metal adapter before plugging them into the DVR.  Even then, the adapters are loose.  The slightest tap against one of the camera leads near the back of the DVR results in a dropped picture and annoying beeping until you jiggle the cables enough to somehow reconnect the cameras. I appreciate the loss of camera alarm but it should be much harder to break the connection between the cameras and the DVR.The quality of the hard drive in the DVR is poor.  The drive in my unit died after about two months.  I have no idea why.  I located the unit in a protected, stable, air conditioned space.  It was never dropped, jarred, or otherwise treated roughly.  I hoped to find information on the problem on the Defender-USA web site.  I was wrong.  There is no on-line support.  In fact, there is very little community support for this product at all.  I am sure the warranty would cover a new drive but I have not gone that route because I got my DVR through the Amazon Vine Program.  Besides, I would not want another of the same kind of drive.There there is the internet viewing option.  Be aware, unless you have a static-ip through your ISP, you will have to go through port-forwarding in order to see your cameras images from a remote computer.  The manual that ships with the unit does not provide instructions on how to do this.  Instead, Defender sends you to portforward,com.  I followed all the port forwarding instructions and actually did get multiple ports to forward.  Trouble is, every time I forwarded a port capable of handling http traffic, I found my ISP had blocked it or some other problem kept the Defender from connecting to the net.  In the meantime, though, I set up other remote controlled apps using the port forwarding knowledge I gained.I can't fully fault the Defender system for my inability to use the view anywhere internet functionality.  However, the Defender-USA promotional material touts this connectivity as a huge selling point.  It neglects to point out, however, that it is difficult to set up and one's ISP may not permit it.In summary, the Defender SN300-4CH-001 is a cheap, low quality system delivering less than high quality images using antiquated, archaic technology.  From the set-up menu to the cameras to the DVR, it is clear Defender-USA's goal in developing this product was assemble the cheapest components, dress them up with slick packaging, and market the finished product as an entry level surveillance system.  Trouble is, when one is talking about a system that should have 24/7 up time, be rock solid reliable, and be capable of delivering footage or images upon which police could base a prosecution, cheap-cheap-cheap doesn't cut it.  Inexpensive is fine, just not cheap.

Reviews.Title: Kind of disappointing
Reviews.Author: Gene Twilley "GTwilley"
Reviews.Content: The reality is that this system is *not* web ready. When I read web ready, my first thought is that I should be able to plug this into my computer to get it up and running. Instead, you need a television in order to use this first (this is not clear in the description; while most people own a television and this isn't a huge problem for them, I don't own a television because I don't need one and this necessitates my going out to purchase one). Many of the other complaints I'd have, especially about the outdoors, have been well documented by others here - so I won't go too much into that.I will say, on the plus side, that the setup is pretty easy. The cords provided help for fast setup and the system is decent for what it is.

Reviews.Title: Easy to setup system that looked dated when it was released is positively obsolete now
Reviews.Author: Omar Siddique
Reviews.Content: An easy-to-configure system falls down on optics, speed, flexibility, and a rat's nest of cables and adapters.I've used a variety of consumer camera gear, including several "IP" models, and at work we run a modest network of a 2 dozen IP-addressable enterprise-grade Axis cameras with two recording stations.  Based on my experience, neither the optics nor the design of this product is up to par.Optical quality is "ok" under artificial light, but colors fade to grey under decreased brightness levels.  Pointing the cameras out the window at night (at an area lit by a bright streetlight) shows only dull blurs on the screen.Color reproduction is far from faithful, even under bright lighting.  My orange tabby cat looks dull orange-grey in the camera view, going to B&W; w/ a hint of tan at close range.  One of the cameras was showing quaint analogue flickers, even though its cord ran across only the DVR itself (no proximity to interference that the other cameras didn't also experience).  The picture looks like a cross between how security cams are depicted on old TV shows and a first-generation camera-phone.The default UI is simple to understand, but a bit annoying.  You can't use the menu while recording.  The default setting has every keypress beeping loudly.  The remote control only works straight-on from the front of the unit.  The onboard interface is a bit slow if you're searching for something, and begs to have a mouse+keyboard instead.The PC interface requires ActiveX, and therefore Internet Explorer browser, which has become less common and less popular in the last few years.  I have used old UIs that require ancient versions of IE, which are no longer available or would be unwise to use.  ActiveX-only is a poor design choice for longevity.There's no audio.  The cabling has various adapters for power and RCA connections, making for a mess of adapters that would make you think you had a lot more than 4 cameras.  The only video output from the DVR is RCA over a BNC (coax) adapter-- really??  Not even VGA or S-video, much less common HDMI?.The drive writes continuously during operation, presumably not buffering to RAM first, and since the camera view is static, it must not be using modern image formats (that store the differences between each frame, rather than each frame individually) such as MJPEG or MPEG, either.  I suspect this unit would soon suffer a failed drive if actually used for 24-hour security purposes.Some nice touches: Everything you need is included, the cameras have integrated wall-mount bases and even an anchor/screw packet per camera.  Virtually no configuration is required.Defender has tried to make setup and use simple for what is normally a rather complex project.  On simplicity, they have succeeded, but not so much in usability or utility.  For this small number of cameras, the dedicated DVR device drives the cost higher than simply running an application on a PC (which the consumer of this product would almost certainly have).  Wireless cameras were cheap enough back then to be an alternative, and definitely are cheap enough now.  All the wiring management is just not necessary when dealing with 1-4 low-end cameras.Since this is not Defender's newest model, their more recent and higher-end gear may be more usable, but for a small personal deployment, this DVR + dumb-camera approach is terribly outmoded.This DVR system may have been acceptable (if not special) for indoor-only usage when it was released.  Today, it is too simple, too slow, too low-end.  Not recommended.

Reviews.Title: terrible at least
Reviews.Author: Nomadic PC User "Chef"
Reviews.Content: I bought it through Amazon a couple of years ago. From the beginning, the display screen worked through TCP/IP and then after a while it would stop working. I thought it was ok at first. Well the condition got worse and now I have to constantly turn it on and off to get the display working for 10 seconds. So much for the name defender. Defective is more like it.

Reviews.Title: customer service
Reviews.Author: Howie
Reviews.Content: If anything goes wrong expect absolutely no customer service. I wouldn't wish this on anyone that's how bad it is.

Reviews.Title: Awful expensive for a paperweight
Reviews.Author: TwitchyGuy
Reviews.Content: I have owned this DVR for 13 months now and it is worthless. I have not been able to view the video remotely with this device, ever, and their 24 hour customer support is only available from 9-5 Est. After hours they forward to a answering service that just submits a callback request for you. Also trying to get a hold of someone between those hours or trying to get someone to call you back in a timley manner is just slightly less frustrating than slamming your thingy in a car door, repeatedly. At around 12.5 months 2 of the supplied cameras died and I called to see if they could help me out since I was just barley out from under warranty. I also checked to see what time and date the cameras died on by reviewing the footage (the DVR will store up to one year) and found out that the hard drive had crashed and was completley usless. After leaving 4 voice mails, 2 emails, and waiting about a week for a callback that was promised within 24 hours, I missed the call and was left a message that simply said that I should call back. Fat chance.Save your money and buy 4 dummy cameras, like this unit you will give the ILLUSION that your property is secure but unlike this unit you will not be disappointed when it comes time to review important video footage that isn't there.

Reviews.Title: No Hard Drive
Reviews.Author: Sarah "chupoarroz"
Reviews.Content: I recently purchased this 4 camera system.  The cameras work great and the system was very easy to set up.  My only complaint that the 5GB hard drive that was supposed to come with it is apparently defective.  The system can find no hard drive onto which to record the video coming in from the cameras.  This system is essentially useless to me since I do not have the time to watch the camera feed live.  If I had the time to do this I would not have bought a system with a DVR.  Also the 24/7 support is non-existant.  The company is unreachable by phone or live chat as they advertise.  This leads me to wonder about the legitimacy of the company as well as the product I have purchased.

Reviews.Title: No
Reviews.Author: John M. Callahan "Book Reader"
Reviews.Content: Power supply for the cameras died at 6 months.3 cameras died, all mounted under my porch areas at 10 months.When the cameras did work they would turn on and off at times, not giving video feed.Video quality is poor, at 20ft you would not be able to tell one guy from another.

Reviews.Title: unreliable
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Brownee"
Reviews.Content: I purchased item in sept device started malfunctioning in march 2011. Merchandise records for 14 days then resets on 15th day with no recordin. My car was vandelism on the 15th day apple ipod stolen and radar detector stolen to. I went to check recordings system had turned itself off I had to call svat/ defender they told me they would replace it but I had to pay to ship to them and they would pay to ship merchandise back to me, tech told me to unplug unit and wait 10 seconds then plug it back up still did not 30 mins later system started back to recording on its on what a waist of 449.00 purchase price and it did not protect my property or allow me to view who did vandelism my property, then they tell me I will not get a new dvr for 3 to 4 weeks once they have received the faulty one they need to check it to see what the problem is.

Reviews.Title: Unreliable!!!
Reviews.Author: murphys law
Reviews.Content: I ordered this system in April 2010 after hvaing some strange occurences in our neighborhood. Nothing had happened at our home yet, but several of our neighbors had been having issues. We thought we would be ahead of the curve and be able to catch anything that happened. Within 2 weeks of installing the system the dvr began to erase our recordings, would change the dates, and reset itself to the factory settings for color (which were completely off, green would look purple when on factory settings.)The lights would blink constantly until we called tech support and they walked us through the reset process and told us that would fix the problem, but if we had any more concerns to feel free to call back. We checked it about an hour later and same problem, so we tried to call tech support, but it was now 5 oclock on Friday and they were closed for the weekend. my husband called the following week and went through several more processes. rewired the system, changed the settings. One month later same issues, My husband worked with tech support again to try to fix the problem, again they assured us that the problem was fixed. Things went fine for a while. Finally the night came, someone jumped the fence of our yard and tried to come in the back door of our home. Luckily our dog was there and alerted us that there was a problem. I have a large guard dog, and was lucky that he scared the people enough to make them run so fast they left a shoe behind. however, when we called the police and went to check our footage, the DVR had stopped recording 3 weeks earlier and never signaled to us that something was wrong. i would never recommend this product and feel that the product description is incredibly misleading. this system was anything but "worry free recording". i bought a new camera system from best buy and we put that up (which by the way works great, has a way better picture and even has sound, but it does cost alot more)

Reviews.Title: defender security camera
Reviews.Author: Anthony Mendola
Reviews.Content: easy hook up. picture quality good. you just have to remember to pull out the plug when you finish recording. the security camera I had before this I never shut it off after two years the system was no good.

Reviews.Title: Defender Security System
Reviews.Author: Basil MacDougal
Reviews.Content: I was SO happy to get this system!  There are a couple of issues that made me want to get this for my home.  First, someone stole my van right out of my driveway last year.  Someone has also broken into my other car and attempted to steal it.  Having a security system like this in place would, I think, deter someone from trying to steal and/or help catch them if they do take something.  I really think just having the cameras in place would be enough to stop them.The second issue is that I have a 15 year old who has been tempted to try to sneak out of the house at night.  Now, with cameras on constantly in the front and rear of our house (and we have 2 dogs that yap constantly inside the house) I feel he will not be attempting to sneak out anytime soon. :)Hook up of the system was a breeze.  The instructions were very clear and I had no trouble at all.  Running the wires through our attic was not hard although it was time consuming.  I was tempted to call a service person (the company can recommend some for you).  But, I'm a do-it-yourselfer and it really wasn't as bad as I thought it might be.  It's always a little intimidating to try something new.  However, like I said, it turned out to be very simple.The picture quality is great and I enjoy watching the video from my computer (located in my office in the back of our house).  I can clearly see if anyone is coming up to the house.  This is great!  I should have gotten one of these long ago.

Reviews.Title: What hard drive?
Reviews.Author: MEP
Reviews.Content: Less than three months the second dvr went out, no hard drive displayed on screen. The cheap Lowes system worked better. Customer service was good but I want a working system not new friends at the repair center. Will not buy another one.

Reviews.Title: Great Cameras
Reviews.Author: E. Moseley "Papanomoe"
Reviews.Content: Great camera and dvr. The internet viewing is a bit more than most novice can handle, but not impossible. Highest quality with 4 cameras lasts about 3 days before it starts to rewrite. Ease of set up depends on how you have to run the cables. Over all it was a good buy.

Reviews.Title: Good Value But Not An Easy Installation
Reviews.Author: Lemon
Reviews.Content: This is a nicely built system that arrives very well-equipped and with thorough instructions and a good web site for back-up. However, it is a wired system, which means you have to run extensive wiring to each camera, and mounting and placing the DVR can be difficult for the novice installer.  While I was able to get the system operational, I was unhappy with my amateurish installation (I want a much cleaner and professional look and don't want wires hanging around), so I am going to make the investment of having one of their professional installers come and re-install.  Luckily, the company offers a network of installers.

Reviews.Title: Lasted only a month ....
Reviews.Author: Cupcakes for tomorow
Reviews.Content: To call the Defender manufacturer (which is based somewhat in Canada, but has a US shipping port, which you have to pay for): 1-866-580-9717This only lasted me a month. I tried to find a good security system, and checking amazon it had the most good reviews while in a budget range.MAIN POINT why I didn't like it: Took too much time troubleshooting every little thing, had to try different methods of seeing what it liked (sometimes it needed to rest so i had to yank the power cord to turn it off from overheating because it COULDN'T RECORD 24/7 ...memory-wise yes, but the parts felt like it couldn't take the heat).--------->The hard drive was the last straw!!!! Kept saying "no hard disk detected" had to try it on a different TV...weird.CONS:-cameras are all wired, not ideal for people who have upstairs or downstairs.-relies only on remote, a mix and match of remote and controls on the DVR doesn't cooperate-firmware is out of date, if you go to the website it looks like it's from some third-rate company,-their 24-hour support is actually some voice-machine that's set to return your call in a day.-oddly, it won't record on the times I really depended on itGOOD:NICE clear cameras, night vision is not good at all, it needs some light to get something decent.ADVICE:find some place local and get one, at least you can take it to the store and yell at them. Amazon's return policy is only 30 days ... I had it for only 20 days since the shipping rate took awhile (even if you pay express shipping), so I felt cheated out of the return.It doesn't matter how much you pay for Defender products, just save yourself time and money by getting a different brand, or just invest in a door alarm or wait a couple of more years until they develop something better.*******UPDATEI called amazon, told them my story about how cruddy the service was with the manufacture and how I would have to pay for shipping for a faulty part, and how SQUARE WARRANTY wouldn't even cover it until 2 months later, they gave me a "refund" on the product with free shipping. Never again will I shop anything "Defender" related, what a horrible company with poor credentials.

Reviews.Title: Installation Requires Running Cable & Setup Only on TV/monitor (Not Computer)
Reviews.Author: SanjeevP "Bottom Line"
Reviews.Content: I ordered this product through Amazon Vine under the impression that the cameras are wireless because the product description says "Do-it-yourself system allows you to set up and monitor your property without the need for a professional installer" and "Fast & Hassle-Free Setup". After receiving the product and reading the manual I found out that you have to run four 60 feet cables to the cameras, and 60 feet won't even reach 2 sides of the house. Not only that, you cannot hide or lock the DVR because it has to be hooked to the TV monitor and a smart burglar will steal the DVR too! You cannot do the setup on the computer monitor or through the network, it has to be done on the TV. So the DVR & TV have to be in the same room with an ethernet port if you are going to monitor on the computer. I think the company needs to be explicit about the installation process and not mislead the buyers with descriptions like that. The only clue that the cameras are hooked to the DVR by cable is the small print "4 x 60ft 4 PIN DIN to RCA (male) Power Cables" under What's in the Box. It could be a useful system for a small business premise but I find it too cumbersome to install and useful in very few situations.

Reviews.Title: Does what it says it will
Reviews.Author: Kaleidocherry
Reviews.Content: It took us a long time to achieve success with this item, but that is because the laptop we were trying to use as the command post had some problems.  So in order to review it, we had to set it up, let it run for a week, then disconnect the DVR unit and move it into our TV room, connect it to the TV, and watch it there.  A minor inconvenience for testing, but I wouldn't want to do it all the time.The product has an easy setup.  We posted one camera looking out the window towards a protected "tree save"; one camera looking from that windowsill back into the room (just for testing) and one camera upstairs, looking down and out onto the tree save.  We have frequently seen raccoons, deer and our own cats roaming around in there, so we assumed there would be some interesting wildlife footage, even if it were just our own cats poking around looking for mice.The cameras are motion-sensitive so we knew there would be some disconnect in the footage.  We used the TV menu to set it to continue recording for 30 seconds after the motion is detected.  They are also supposed to be night-vision cameras, so we were interested to see that.After a week we moved the DVR to the TV room and connected it.  The upstairs camera hadn't recorded a thing.  Turns out I'd connected the camera to the DVR, but forgotten to plug the camera into its power source.  OK, my bad.  The camera looking into the room had a lot of footage of me and my son going back and forth prepping for school, or cleaning, or whatever.  It worked, but of course the stuff it filmed was really boring.  We had high hopes for the downstairs tree save camera.Augh.  We hadn't considered that trees moving in the wind would generate motion.  We have a solid week of recorded trees waving in the wind.  No animals, and more importantly, no night-vision recording.  It simply stopped recording at night.  There is a time and date stamp on it, so we knew it was skipping that time frame - not that it was recording a black screen.  It's possible that the window/screen was causing too much visual blockage, so the camera couldn't see outside.  Maybe if you mounted the cameras outside it would work.The other issue I had was the cords.  If you were going to use this in any kind of *indoor* real-world security situation, you'd probably want to get professional installation.  We have all three of the cameras set up within about 20 feet of each other (not counting the vertical rise for the upstairs one) and there's still a mess of cords all over the place.  When we want to move the DVR to the TV to look at the footage, we have to disconnect all three cameras, unplug the DVR, bring it and its plug into the TV room, replug it, and connect it to the TV input.  It's a bit of a mess.  So I'd suggest (a) a dedicated computer, TV, or laptop for it, and (b)(1) installing it so the cords are run through your walls or (b)(2) mounting the cameras outside and running the cords through the window or wall right at the place where you keep the DVR.We'll probably leave it up for a few weeks to check for outdoor summer footage, and then pack it up.  It's not worth it to us as a security device.  But it works, mostly well (but for the lack of the night-vision thing).  For us that was not a dealbreaker since it is a fun device for us, but for you, if you want night vision, better look elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: Great Value, But Setup is Hardly "Fast & Hassle-Free"
Reviews.Author: shaxper
Reviews.Content: The Sentinel 300 series is a great value in that it provides all the necessary hardware to observe up to four locations inside or outside of your home with clarity, adjustable features/options, and a generous hard drive with which you can record all of this and even connect it to your computer so that you can watch over the internet in real-time while away from your home.The problem I've run into, however, is installation. The product advertises "Fast & Hassle Free" setup, which is true in the sense that you can connect and test the hardware quite quickly. However, actually installing this system is a different ordeal all together. I feel very stupid for not having considered this in advance, but each camera uses wires to connect to the control box. The fact that the wires are hidden in all of the images of the product along with the promise of a "Fast & Hassle Free" setup probably helped me to make this rather large oversight.Essentially, you're going to have to do quite a bit of drilling and behind-wall wire running in order to set this thing up, and that's not an easy job to pull off, even for a do-it-yourselfer. The box provides a toll free number if you need help with installation (which you will), and the number refers you to an outside company where a very nervous and overly eager young man informed me that installation of four cameras WITHOUT hiding the wires would run me over two hundred dollars. It's about a hundred and fifty more if you want wires hidden, and that's a rough quote that they gave without even seeing my home or intended setup. Granted, three hundred fifty plus the six hundred forty dollar purchase price isn't such a high price for a good security system, but it is a bit misleading and, worse yet, requires significant work on and inside your walls, which always makes me nervous.As great a system as the Sentinel 300 promises to be, I will not be installing it in my home. It was probably silly of me not to consider everything that would go into installing this system, but I also think Defender worked pretty hard to help me make that stupid decision, concealing the wires in all photos and promising that setup would be "Fast & Hassle-Free." Until Defender pioneers some amazing wireless camera technology, I will simply have to do without. The Sentinel 300 system is a great option for a small business or a person who is comfortable doing their own wiring or has someone they trust to do it for them correctly, but playing inside of walls when it isn't necessary just seems like an invitation for problems and aggravation.

Reviews.Title: Nice little gadget
Reviews.Author: Rama Rao "Rama"
Reviews.Content: This is a user friendly security system with DVRs built-in 500GB hard drive which can record over 2 years of continuous video. You can access your live or recorded video on any computer using the Internet. This is a simple solution for protecting your family and property. I set this up to see the inside of my house when I am away or when I am at work. I like the ability of the system to switch from quad view to one camera and return to quad again. The picture quality is clear and I have no complaints. The night-vision cameras are a great feature for recording. This is a very affordable little gadget, and it is recommended.1. Logitech WiLife Digital Video Security--Hidden Master System Camera

ProductInfo.Features:
Do-it-yourself system allows you to set up and monitor your property without the need for a professional installer
Record over 2 years of video footage on the built-in 500GB hard drive
Transfer recorded footage directly to your computer using the included USB cable
View video online with no service fees from any computer in the world
24/7 lifetime live customer support is available through phone, email, and live web chat both before and after you buy
ProductInfo.Name: Defender SN300-4CH-001 User-Friendly Web-Ready DVR Security System with 4 Indoor/Outdoor Night-Vision Surveillance Cameras (Black)
